pages.title: What is a condition?
pages.overview: Conditions are requirements that a company must complete to be allowed to construct, operate or abandon a project. Conditions are one tool within the CER's regulatory framework, which is made of laws, regulations, requirements and guidance.

pages.title: Why are conditions made?
pages.overview: Conditions are project-specific. The CER sets them during the application assessment process to prevent harm, promote safety and environmental protection in the public interest.

pages.title: How does the CER verify condition compliance?
pages.overview: The CER verifies company compliance with project condition requirements through compliance verification activities (i.e. inspections, audits, etc.) and assessing condition filings.

guide.clickOutside: Click outside circle to go back

featureDescription.theme: To facilitate analysis and public understanding, conditions are grouped into themes such as environment, finance, safety, security, etc.
featureDescription.phase: As a lifecycle regulator, the CER ensures the safety and protection of the environment throughout all phases of a project. Conditions can apply to one, several or all phases of the lifecycle. Learn more about {phaseLink}.
featureDescription.status: There are two possible status for conditions: In Progress and Closed.
featureDescription.type: There are two main types of conditions: standard and non-standard.
featureDescription.filing: A document that demonstrates the fulfillment of a condition’s requirements.
featureDescription.instrument:
Orders, certificates, licenses or permits issued by the CER (previously the NEB). All instruments have an instrument prefix and number (i.e. GC-115).
All regulatory instrument prefixes with associated conditions are listed and defined in the right panel.
The CER publishes a {instrumentLink} that lists Regulatory Instruments issued from September 2014 to current.

featureTypesDescription.allThemes: * Conditions with multiple themes are counted more than once.
featureTypesDescription.otherInstruments: * The graph above shows the top nine types of regulatory instruments based on the total number of times they occur in the data. Remaining instrument types are grouped into the 'Other' category. The definitions below contain the complete list of regulatory instrument types in the data.

theme.ADMINISTRATIVE: Conditions that help track organizational tasks.
theme.DAMAGE_PREVENTION: Conditions that hold companies accountable for the safe conduct in and around pipelines and facilities.
theme.EMERGENCY_MANAGEMENT: Conditions that ensure companies have a robust program that anticipates and prevents incidents, and manages and mitigates situations during an emergency.
theme.ENFORCEMENT: Conditions that reinforce prescribed regulatory requirements to be met.
theme.ENVIRONMENTAL_PROTECTION: Conditions that mandate projects to be planned, built, operated or abandoned in a manner that protects the environment.
theme.FINANCIAL: Conditions that require certain details or all aspects of a company’s financial obligations be fulfilled.
theme.INTEGRITY_MANAGEMENT: Conditions that ensure projects are designed, built, operated and maintained in a safe and effective manner. For instance, the use of appropriate materials, the detection of corrosion, etc.
theme.MANAGEMENT_SYSTEM: Company specific conditions that ensure the use of an effective and efficient approach to manage and reduce risk. Note: A management system is not project specific.
theme.SAFETY_MANAGEMENT: Conditions that eliminate or reduce risk to the public, workers, the environment and assets.
theme.SECURITY: Conditions that ensure companies have adequate personnel and systems to deter, respond and manage security threats.
theme.SOCIO_ECONOMIC: Conditions that address the concerns of potentially affected landowners, residents, communities, indigenous groups, etc.
theme.STANDARD_CONDITION: A condition that is typically imposed on all approved projects.
theme.SUNSET_CLAUSE: Conditions that ensure projects begin within a specific period of time.

phase.ABANDONMENT: If a company wants to abandon a pipeline or facility, it must submit an application to the CER, including an environmental and socio-economic assessment.  The CER will assess the application and may hold a public hearing. The CER may impose conditions on an abandonment project.
phase.DURING_CONSTRUCTION_PHASE: The CER will monitor and verify compliance with the regulatory instrument’s conditions during the construction phase through compliance verification activities (CVAs).
phase.EXPIRY_DATE_OF_REG_INSTR: If construction has not commenced prior to the expiry dates, the instrument and all conditions are null and void.
phase.INCLUDES_ALL_PHASES_OF_CONSTR: Some conditions apply at all phases of construction (prior, during and post construction).
phase.NOT_CONSTRUCTION_RELATED: Some conditions apply outside of the construction context.
phase.POST_CONSTRUCTION_PHASE: After construction is complete, the CER continues to regulate the post-construction activities carried out by the company through compliance verification activities (CVAs).
phase.PRIOR_TO_THE_CONSTRUCTION_PHASE: Before construction can begin, conditions assigned must be fulfilled.
phase.UNSPECIFIED: Phase is not specified or applicable.

status.CLOSED:
This status refers to:
• condition requirements that have been satisfied, and no further submissions from the company are required; or
• conditions whose filings or actions apply to a specific phase that have been fulfilled as the phase is completed (i.e. a specific filing during construction phase). Note: comments on the required actions can still be received.
status.IN_PROGRESS:
This status refers to conditions that continue to be monitored by the CER. This happens when:
• condition filings have not yet been received by the CER; or,
• filings have been received but are under review or do not yet meet requirements; or,
• a project is not completed and it has conditions, which have not been met; or,
• a project has a post-construction condition, but a requirement has not yet been completed; or,
• some conditions may be active indefinitely or refer to the continued operation of a pipeline.

The CER follows up on in-progress conditions.

type.STANDARD: A condition that is typically imposed on all approved projects.
type.NON_STANDARD: Non-standard conditions capture project-specific information or concerns that are not addressed by standard conditions.

filing.REQUIRED: A company must file a document with the CER in order to comply with a condition. The CER reviews these filings.
filing.NOT_REQUIRED: A company is not required to file a document with the CER in order to comply with a condition. Some conditions are covered by filings for another related condition. If a condition does not require a company to file a document, the CER can verify compliance during a compliance verification activity (CVA) such as an inspection or audit.

instrument.AO: The approval of an amendment as to content or conditions of any Certificate, License, Order or Permit (in some cases the approval of the Governor in Council is required).
instrument.EC: The approval of the construction and/or operation of an international power line
instrument.EP: The approval of the construction and operation of an international power line
instrument.EPE: The approval of the export of power and/or energy
instrument.FRO: The approval to provide more direct access to financial resources, including readily accessible types
instrument.GC: The approval of the construction of a new gas pipeline or additional gas pipeline
instrument.GPL: The approval of the Plans, Profiles, and Books of Reference for a new or additional gas pipeline. Also used in connection with deviations required in existing gas pipelines
instrument.GPLO: The approval of the opening of a new or additional gas pipelines or deviations thereof
instrument.GPMO: The approval of the opening of a gas meter station or parts thereof
instrument.GPSO: The approval of the opening of a gas compressor station, gas plant or parts thereof
instrument.MO: The approval of miscellaneous matters, such as upgrading of maximum authorized operation pressures, conveyance, sale or lease of a pipeline or parts thereof, abandonment of pipelines, etc.
instrument.OC: The approval of the construction of a new oil pipeline or additional oil pipeline
instrument.OPLO: The approval of the opening of a new or additional oil pipelines or derivations thereof
instrument.OPSO: The approval of the opening of an oil pump station or parts thereof and terminal facilities
instrument.SG: The requirements for gas pipeline company to repair, reconstruct or alter part of a gas pipeline, etc., for safety reasons
instrument.SO: The requirements for an oil pipeline company to repair, reconstruct or alter part of an oil pipeline etc., for safety reasons
instrument.TG: The fixing of tariffs and tolls – gas pipelines
instrument.TO: The fixing of tariffs and tolls – oil pipelines
instrument.XC: The exemption of a commodity pipeline or parts thereof, or commodity pipeline facilities
instrument.XG: The exemption of a gas pipeline or parts thereof, or gas pipeline facilities (Class B)
instrument.XO: The exemption of an oil pipeline or parts thereof, or oil facilities (Class B)
instrument.GH: The setting of a hearing process for a new additional gas pipeline and/or the export of/or import of gas
instrument.OH: The setting of a hearing process for a new or additional oil pipeline
instrument.XE: The exemption from certification for an international power line (pre 1990)
instrument.MH: The setting of a hearing date for matters not covered by s.24(6) for various reasons
instrument.OPL: The approval of the Plans, Profiles and Books of Reference for a new or additional oil pipeline. Also used in connection with deviation required in existing pipelines

suggestedKeywordsPopout.keywordsDescription: Keywords capture the general idea of a condition, e.g. type of species regulated. Learn more about {here} keywords.

content.methodology: Click {here} to download a PDF file explaining our data collection methodology.

keywords.1:
How do we get keywords?
When parts of a condition’s text match keywords from the Master List they become the keywords for that condition.
keywords.2:
Where did the Master List come from?
1. Manual processing was used to extract an initial set of words from the CER Condition Guide
 … an internal document that guides the creation of all conditions.
keywords.3:
2. The initial set was expanded through text mining
synonyms
keywords.5: 3. Additional lists of locations and community names were added to create the Master List
keywords.6:
How are keywords categorized?
The Master List of keywords was manually grouped into the following areas: Wildlife & Habitat, Environment, Oversight & Safety, Engineering & Structures, Administration & Filings and, People & Communities.

content.downloadData: Click {here} to download the dataset in CSV (comma-separated values) format.
content.about:
This Conditions on Energy Projects interactive online tool is part of the Canada Energy Regulator’s (CER) Data Visualization Initiative (DVI). The DVI is a three-year initiative to transform how the CER (previously the NEB) structures and shares data. The objective is to enable evidence-based decision making and remove barriers to understanding Canada’s energy and pipeline systems through the use of user-friendly interactive visualizations. This visualization is based on CER data from 2010 to current for conditions on CER-regulated energy projects.
If you want to use the data for research and undertake your own review, all the data is downloadable and shareable.
We hope we are hitting the mark. Your feedback is essential.
content.emailUs: Email us with your comments and ideas: {email}. We look forward to hearing from you.

totalConditions.title: How is the Total Number of Conditions Determined?
totalConditions.explanation: The total number of conditions displayed in the visualization may not match the CER's published total number of conditions attached to a project. Some conditions are repeated in several instruments for a single project, and the visualization counts conditions each time they appear in an instrument.
totalConditions.example: For example, a project may have 10 unique conditions reported, but if one of these conditions is repeated in 6 different instruments for that project, the visualization will display a count of 15 conditions for that project.

data.title: Data Download
data.description: The data used to create this visualization is open data available for you to download. Click the icon to save the data file to your computer.

company.name: Full Project Name:
company.meaningHeading: Why is there more than one company associated with this project?
company.meaningText:
There are instances when more than one company has obligations related to a project. Examples include:
 - an agreement between one company to sell and another company to purchase a pipeline; and
 - CER initiatives that address regulatory gaps. (i.e. Abandonment Cost Estimate and Set-Aside Mechanism).

regdocs.found: Instrument found, click to open document.
regdocs.whatIsText: RegDocs is a collection of publically accessible documents that are filed onto the legal record for hearings or other written regulatory proceedings. These documents originate from the Company Applicants, the CER, and various participants in the regulatory processes. Technical staff and Board Members use these documents when considering project applications and other regulatory matters.

shareIcon.emailBody: This is an interactive tool for exploration of CER conditions data through keywords and visual representation.

disclaimer.heading: Disclaimer
disclaimer.text: The conditions which appear in this visualization have been transcribed or copied from the regulatory instruments as issued. In the event of any discrepancy, either in English or French, between text of a condition as it appears in this visualization and the text in the regulatory instrument, the regulatory instrument prevails.
